intro: Argemone mexicana var. rosea, commonly known as the rosea variant of the Mexican prickly poppy, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its striking pink to reddish-purple flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant features narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces capsules that contain seeds with a high oil content. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in disturbed areas such as roadsides and fields. Botanically, it belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae and is known for its ornamental value and potential medicinal uses.
